clinical_study.brief_title: Plaque Registration and Event Detection In Computed Tomography
clinical_study.official_title: Prospective Multicenter Study to Investigate the Relationship Between the Characteristics of Coronary Artery Plaques and Cardiovascular Events Using Multidetector Computed Tomography Coronary Angiography

brief_summary.textblock: Disruption of an atherosclerotic plaque is responsible for at least two-thirds of acute coronary syndrome. Thus, identification of plaques vulnerable to rupture has become important. The natural history of individual plaques is unknown and needs to be established. Multidetector computed tomography (MDCT) angiography is a useful noninvasive imaging modality for assessing coronary plaque characteristics. Using MDCT, the researchers prospectively investigate the relationship between the characterization of coronary plaques and cardiovascular events in a large multicenter study.

primary_outcome.measure: Major cardiac events (Cardiac death and acute coronary syndrome)

secondary_outcome.measure: All coronary events (Cardiac death, non-fatal MI, unstable angina requiring hospitalization, late coronary revascularizations)
All cardiovascular events (Death, acute coronary syndrome, heart failure, cerebral disease, peripheral artery disease, aortic disease, and renal failure)

other_outcome.measure: Coronary plaque progression and managements for serum cholesterol, blood glucose, renal function and blood pressure: Especially impacts of statin on the changes in coronary plaque characteristics

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients with known or suspected coronary artery disease.
Exclusion Criteria:
- irregular heart beat,
- known allergy towards the contrast agent,
- renal dysfunction,
- uncontrolled heart failure,
- previous coronary bypass surgery, or pacemaker or ICD implantation, ST elevation MI or unstable hemodynamic condition,
- impossible breath-hold, OR
- end-stage cancer.
